loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Amor Y Paz se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Calderón de la  ciudad de Portoviejo, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos.

La señora Ana esta en el Banco Comunal desde sus inicios y le ha gustado tanto que ya son 12 años que es socia. Tiene 46 años y está casada hace 26 años, tiene tres hijos ya mayores de edad, su esposo se dedica al comercio.

Se dedica junto a su esposo al comercio en lo que es compra y venta de productos agrícolas, venden tamarindo cocinado por libras, maní en grano y molido, achiote y otros productos más, al por mayor y menor. Trabajan todos los días de 4 am hasta las 15h00 y cuando tiene que hacer recorridos hasta la noche, ya que además de entregar en la localidad, también se desplaza a otras ciudades, como Manta, Portoviejo y Quevedo. Los productos los compran a los agricultores de la zona. Los procesa u después los lleva a entregar.

Este crédito lo va a utilizar en comprar más productos para tener en reserva para cuando se escasee ya que son productos que se pueden guardar por un buen tiempo.

Sus metas son seguir adelante y quizás después comprar un carro para realizar sus ventas.
texts.en:
The Amor y Paz community bank meets every two weeks in the Calderon Parish in the town of Portoviejo. The townspeople are involved in agriculture, raising animals and selling their products. Ana has been with the bank since its inception. She has enjoyed been a partner for the last 12 years. She is 46 years old, has been married for 26 years and has three adult children. Her husband works in commerce. She works with her husband buying and selling produce. They sell cooked tamarind by the pound, ground and whole peanuts, achiote and others, retail and wholesale. They work every day from 4am to 3pm and until evening when they need to do deliveries. Besides delivering in town they also go to other towns such as Manta, Portoviejo and Quevedo. Local producers buy their products. They process the products and deliver them back. They will use the loan to purchase more products to have some in stock when supplies come down since these products can be stored for a good amount of time. Their goal is to strive ahead and maybe later buy a car to make their sales.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprar tamarind, peanuts, achiote, etc.

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita T. is from the village of Lobao, Extension, Iligan City. She is 60 years old. Florita is widowed and has 1 child. To make a living, Florita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Florita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Florita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Florita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lobao, Extension, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en: Tuya B. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and five children in the Uvs province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest two children, aged 18 and 20, are students who currently live and study in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband Batsaihan runs a farming business, while Tuya operates a business selling religious items at the local market. They started both businesses in 2007. After years of successful operations, Tuya has managed to increase her working capital of religious items to over 1,000,000 MNT today. For the farming business, they plant various types of vegetables and crops on their own 7 hectares of land. Specifically, they plant wheat on 2 hectares of their land and grass on 5 hectares. They usually harvest 10 tons of variety of vegetables such as potatoes, carrots and beets, and sell these products within 10 to 12 months. For the future, they are planning to hire a new employee for their family business. Tuya is a very hardworking person and says, “All I want is to change my small agriculture business into a big farm." She is requesting a 2,700,000 MNT loan to purchase more fuel for a truck that is used as a transportation vehicle for their products.

loans.use: To purchase fuel for agricultural transport

loans.name: Paula Moserrate

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Amor Y Paz se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Calderón de la  ciudad de Portoviejo, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos.

La señora Paula tiene 36 años y está casada hace 20 años, tiene 4 hijos el mayor estudia en la Universidad, y los otros dos  en colegio, uno de sus hijos falleció hace dos años atrás, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura.

Se dedica junto a su esposo y  sus hijos a la agricultura y a la venta de sus productos, cultivan plátano, yuca, y maní.  Venden estos productos y derivados de estos como el almidón. Trabajan en el campo desde las siete hasta las tres de la tarde, y sus productos los lleva a vender a Manta, Chone y Portoviejo, los fines de semana en los que dedican casi todo el día. Trabajan con ellos seis personas a los cuales les pagan su jornal para su sustento.

Este nuevo crédito lo va a utilizar en comprar mas productos e insumos para la agricultura además de almidón ya que este se vende a buen precio en la ciudad. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el principio, es socia fundadora y le gusta por la ayuda que ha recibido.
 
Sus metas son que sus hijos sean profesionales y mejorar día a día.
texts.en:
The “Amor y Paz” (Love and Peace) communal bank meets every two weeks in Portoviejo’s Calderón parish. Most of the residents of this location are farmers and raise animals to sell. Paula, 36, has been married for 20 years and has had four children. The oldest is in the University and the other two are in school. One of her children died two years ago. Her husband is a farmer. She, her husband and her children work in farming and sell what they grow. They farm bananas, manioc and peanuts. They sell these products and derivatives of them, like tapioca starch. They work the fields from 7am until 3pm and they take their products to Manta, Chone and Portoviejo to sell on weekends spending most of the day selling. They have six employees who they pay a daily wage for their support. This new loan will be used to buy more farming supplies as well as more tapioca starch because it sells for a good price in the city. She has been in the communal bank since its inception; she’s a founding member an she likes it because of the help she has received. Her goals are that her children become professionals and to improve day by day.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy some farming supplies and some tapioca The “Amor y Paz” (Love and Peace) communal bank meets every two weeks in Portoviejo’s Calderón parish.  Most of the residents of this location are farmers and raise animals to sell.starch.

loans.name: Carmen Amparo

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Amor Y Paz se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Calderón de la  ciudad de Portoviejo, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos.

La señora amparo se desempeña como tesorera del Banco Comunal, es socia fundadora y le gusta porque siempre ha recibido los créditos a tiempo.
 
Está casada hace 20 años y tiene tres hijos, uno ya es mayor de edad y todos  están estudiando. Tienen una finca en la que cultivan plátano y cacao.

Tienen un negocio familiar, se dedican a la producción de chifles (plátano frito). Trabajan todos los días 9 horas al día y se reparten las tares que hay que realizar ya que además de elaborar el producto también se encargan de distribuirlo en las diferentes tiendas de la localidad y también entregan en Rocafuerte en algunas tiendas. En la fabricación y venta del producto trabajan tres personas además de su familia.

Este crédito lo van a utilizar en comprar aceite, manteca, y plátanos para cumplir con las ventas y los pedidos.
 
Sus sueños son ampliar su negocio y tener maquinarias industriales adecuadas para la fabricación del chifle.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Amor Y Paz” (Love and Peace) meets every 15 days in Calderón Parish in the city of Portoviejo, an area where most of the people engage in farming, raising animals, and selling their products.

Sra. Amparo serves as treasurer of the Communal Bank. She is a founding member and enjoys that distinction because she always receives her loans on time. Amparo has been married for 20 years and has three children, one who is already an adult while the rest are students. She has a farm where she grows bananas and cacao.

In addition to the family business, Amparo makes fried banana chips. Everyone works nine hours each day and shares responsibility for the tasks involved in making this product. Amparo is in charge of distributing her product to different shops in her town as well as a few stores in Rocafuerte. Three people from her family assist her with making and selling this product. This loan will be used to buy oil, butter, and bananas so that she can complete her orders and sales.

Amparo dreams of expanding her business and having adequate industrial machines for making banana chips.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase oil, butter, and bananas

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
Feliza D. is from the village of Kanitoan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Feliza is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Feliza owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community, with her husband as her business partner. Feliza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Feliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services in order to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Feliza is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Feliza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Dulam

texts.en: Dulam A. is 53 years old and lives with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family has been living at their current address for the past 25 years. Her husband is retired and stays at home. She operates a grocery trading business at her rented stall in the local community. She has been engaged in this business since 2007, when she retired on a pension, and since then she has built a stable operation. She sells a variety of meats and fruits to her customers. Dulam is a modest and kind person who says "My business earnings have enabled us to provide for our daily household consumption and I am no longer dependent on my pension money".  Dulam is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more products and to increase her product line.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products for sale

loans.name: Meleane

texts.en:
Meleane F. is 63, and is widowed with 3 children.  She owns a business venture selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community.  Meleane has many years of experience in this business.  Meleane needs a loan of 1,000 talas to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2010, Meleane joined SPBD.  This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Meleane's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her snack selling business

loans.name: Batmunh

texts.en: Batmunh N. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and ten year old son in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. His son attends a local secondary school. Batmunh operates a raw material retail business in his town with the help of his wife. He has been engaged in this business since 1996 and has built his business to a consistent level. After many years of successful operation, he has gained much experience as a businessman. Batmunh is a very modest and hardworking person. Today, he stores his raw materials in a small wooden pavilion. He plans to enlarge his storage capacity for raw materials. He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of raw materials in order to grow his working capital.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of raw materials

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en: Otgonbayar is 42 years old, and lives with her husband and two sons in Ulaanbaatar (the capital city of Mongolia).  The older son, Munkhbayar, is 18 and studies in a University. The younger son, Munkherdene, is 16 and studies in a College. Otgonbayar’s husband Otgonbileg is a blacksmith who makes metal stoves and ovens which are used for cooking and providing warmth in gers (Mongolian traditional nomadic tents). These products are in high demand in Ulaanbaatar- statistics say that about 70% of households in Ulaanbaatar are still living in the ger district. Otgonbayar sells these stoves and ovens in the Narantuul market (the largest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar). They have been running this business since 1998. They live in a ger too, but they managed to buy a plot of land and to send their two sons to University and College. Their main goal is to give a higher education to their kids. Half of the loan Otgonbayar is requesting will be used to pay the University's annual fee for her older son, and the other half will be used to buy metal sheets and materials for producing stoves and ovens.

loans.use: To buy metal sheets and materials for producing stoves and ovens, and to pay her son's annual fee for University

loans.name: Davaanyam

texts.en: Davaanyam H. is 24 years old and lives with his wife and seven year old child in the Hentiy province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His daughter, Nuutshanhusel, attends a local elementary school while his wife is currently unemployed. Davaanyam operates a taxi service. He started driving a taxi in 2004 and has found success. He usually makes 6 round trips a month between Hentiy and Ulaanbaatar with 5 passengers, and earns a revenue of 12,000 MNT from each passenger. His transportation expense is 20,000 MNT for each trip. He has used his earnings to stabilize his family's financial situation and also to operate his business sustainably. Davaanyam hopes to trade in his car for a larger vehicle that can increase his business profits. He is a helpful, honest and hardworking man. He needs funds to pay for his new truck as well as to winterize his house; therefore, he is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan.

loans.use: To buy a new truck and to winterize his house

loans.name: Ganzorig

texts.en: Ganzorig D. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Hentiy province in central Mongolia. His oldest two children currently attend university, and his youngest daughter studies at a local secondary school. His wife works as a construction decorator and earns a salary of 300,000-500,000 MNT during the summer months. He operates a small wood production business in his town. Ganzorig started his wood products business in 2002. By managing and conducting his business successfully he has been able to achieve stable operations, and his monthly revenue reaches up to 800,000 MNT. His earnings have enabled him to support his entire family as well as to operate his business sustainably. He is a helpful, honest and hardworking person. He dreams of opening his own wood production workplace after providing for his son's education. He is requesting a 740,000 MNT loan to buy more wooden timber for his business.

loans.use: To buy more wooden timber

loans.name: Leonicia

texts.en:
Leonicia C. is from the village of Malibago Echague. She is 49 years old. Leonicia is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Leonicia owns and operates a furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Leonicia has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leonicia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services in order to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Leonicia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leonicia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa T. is from the village of Nabannagan, Lasam, Cagayan. She is 37 years old. Luisa is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Luisa owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling vegetable seeds such as beans in the local community. Luisa is just starting her business.

In 2010, Luisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services in order to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Luisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Luisa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable seeds for sale

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline R. is from the village of Flores, Naguillan, Isabela. She is 42 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Evangeline owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Evangeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en: Dolores M. is from the village of Palattao, Naguilian, Isabela. She is 58 years old and is married with three adult children. Dolores owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Dolores joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet N. is from the village of Kanitoan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Janet owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Janet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Janet plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty G. is from the town of Banga. She is 49 years old and is married with four children. She is involved in farming and hog-raising: she plants and harvests rice crops and grows hogs for fattening and sale. She was also able to put up a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells various products. Betty hopes that her ventures will work out so that she has a stable income.

Betty joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Betty is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs, feeds for her pigs, and additional store inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her businesses to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, feeds for her pigs and additional store inventory

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna B. is from the village of Palabotan, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 51 years old and is married with six adult children. Myrna owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Palabotan, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena P. is from the town of Banga in South Cotabato province on the island of Mindanao. She is 50 years old, married and has ten children with the younger ones still going to school. For over ten years Elena has been a farmer who plants and harvests rice to sell. She now raises pigs for fattening as well.

Elena joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is now requesting a loan of 7000 PHP that will be used to purchase farm supplies and feed for the pigs. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and feed for her pigs

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma B. is 46 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Kanitoan within the municipality of Initao, a part of Misamis Oriental province in Northern Mindanao. Thelma has a store from which she buys and sells different varieties of bananas to the local community. She has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Thelma joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Thelma is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional bananas to sell

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita G. is 54 years old, married and has two adult-aged children. She is from the village of Barcolan, a part of Bamban municipality in the central Luzon islands. Rosita has a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. Rosita has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2008 Rosita joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Rosita successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase new items to expand her line of products. Rosita is requesting a new loan, her third from ASKI, of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Muliauma Vitale

texts.en:
M. V. is 42 and married with six children. She plants and harvests taro to sell. M. has many years of experience in this business.

In 2010, M. joined SPBD. SPBD's loans are M.'s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. M. is requesting a loan, her first from SPBD, of 1000 WST to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 WST per week) to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Annah Fe

texts.en:
Annah Fe L. is 24 years old, married and has three small children. She is from the village of Kanitoan in Initao municipality in the province of Misamis Oriental on the Mindanao islands. Annah Fe raises pigs to sell. She has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Annah Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Annah Fe is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Veronica's Group

texts.en:
Veronica B. is 26 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Viga, a part of Angadanan municipality in the province of Isabela on the Luzon islands. Veronica is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Veronica runs a general store from which she sells both food and daily use products to the local community. Veronica has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Veronica joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first from ASKI, of 7000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

Daisy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie B. is 41 years old, married and has four school-aged children. She is from the town of Banga in South Cotabato province in the Southern Mindanao islands. Elvie is a farmer who plants and harvests rice to sell. She also raises pigs for fattening and wants to raise ducks as well.

Elvie joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. Elvie successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is now requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and feed for the pigs and ducklings. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and feed for her pigs and ducklings

loans.name: Puchh

texts.en:
Mrs. Puchh B. (pictured above), sells Khmer noodles, or Num Banh Chok in her village. Khmer noodles are considered the national dish of Cambodia. They can be served with a green curry soup and banana flowers, bean sprouts, water lily stalks and cucumber.

Puchh has four children, one son and three daughters. The family lives along National Road Number Five about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. One of her children is married and lives outside the family home, while two are garment factory workers and another one drives a remorque taxi. A remorque is a motorcycle with a trailer attached to the back.

Unluckily, her son’s trailer has been stolen. So Puchh is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase a new trailer for her son so he will be able to continue in his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new trailer for her son

loans.name: Enkhbold

texts.en:
Mr. Enkhbold, 40, is a widower whose wife died in 2002 of liver cancer. He lives with his only daughter, Dulguun, 19, in Ulaanbaatar city, the capital of Mongolia. Dulguun is on her way to becoming a doctor and studies in medical college in second grade.

Enkhbold has been running a taxi business since 2003 and it is his only source of income. He owns a small piece of land and a family house.

Each year, Enkhbold has to pay 1 million Mongolian tugriks (approximately 750 USD) for his daughter’s annual tuition fee but this year half of the fee will be covered by a Government grant. However, he still needs to pay the rest of the money. The reason Enkhbold is asking for this loan is he wants to pay the rest of the annual tuition fee for his only daughter.

loans.use: To pay his daughter's annual tuition fee

loans.name: Jeoffer

texts.en:
Jeoffer A. is from the town of Banga. He is 31 years old and is married with a 7-year-old child.

Jeoffer owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. He also tills a small parcel of land where he plants and harvests rice crops. He says his harvest helps his family as they use part of it for family consumption. When he is not busy farming and growing hogs, he spends time driving his tricycle to transport people around his community.

Jeoffer joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Jeoffer is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and feed for his pigs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and feed for his pigs

loans.name: Bayanmunh

texts.en:
Bayanmunh B. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His oldest, a son, is a monk and attends a buddhist monastery while his two younger daughters, aged 12 and 13, currently study at a secondary school.

All family members help Bayanmunh with his business. He makes wrestling costumes consisting of a tight shoulder vest (zodog) and shorts (shuudag) and sells his products at Narantuul market once a week. He can make two set of costumes per day. He is a very modest, honest and hardworking person and says: "It is nice to sell products I make myself to my customers."

Bayanmunh is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase materials such as fiber strings, leather and padding as well as to buy a new sewing machine which all will help him continue making traditional wrestling costumes.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and materials for making more traditional wrestling costumes

Mr. Sum B. was not available for the picture, so his wife is pictured.

texts.en:

When Vera's husband died, she had to continue the business that he initially started. She worked hard, learned a lot, and finally was able to sustain the business and even open several more locations to make this business a success. At the moment she’s got 5 locations that provide jobs for 15 employees.

Vera would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventories. Her business goal is to open one more location in her town. She wants to save enough money to be able to help her daughter study at college.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

They are living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

One of his sons finished his baccalaureate; he wants to continue his studies at the university. So Phy is asking for a loan of US$ 1,000 to pay school fees for his son. He will use a part of the loan to purchase additional materials for his business.

loans.name: Kimiyokhon

texts.en:
I. Kimiyokhon is married and has two grown children. For the last decade, she and her husband have made a living by growing vegetables and raising cattle. Last season, the couple managed to raise a bumper crop, and they would like to continue that success this year by planting an even larger crop and raising more cattle. To make this possible, Kimiyokhon and her family are applying for a loan for $1,500. They hope to use the increased income made possible by this loan to improve their standard of living.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Rubaare Twimukye Tukore Group, Ntungamo

texts.en: Used clothing is in high demand in Uganda. Jolly A., a hard-working and energetic woman of 30, has begun tapping into that demand by buying consignments of used clothing for resale. She is a member of the Rubaare Twimukye Tukore loan group, whose eight members we see here. Jolly has done very well with her business, as proved by the 160,000 Ugandan shillings she makes monthly. She is taking a long view and has drawn up a plan to expand her used clothing business into a much larger operation, and is applying for this loan to help make that expansion possible.  Her goal is to be able to pay for the education of her four children, and help her family live a better life.

loans.use: to buy more used clothing to sell to her customers.

Daniel envisions expanding his business into wholesale and this will attract many customers to his shop. Earning more revenue and making the business expand is his main motive in this case so as to live a self-sustaining life as he looks at educating his children.

loans.name: Tuichiboy

texts.en:
Tuichiboy S. is 51 years old. He is married with three children. His wife is a housekeeper who looks after their children. Tuichiboy is the only breadwinner in the family and he is really hard-working. He has a cafe where he sells locally-inspired meals and foodstuff. He has been in the business for almost 30 years. Tuichiboy tries to have fresh foodstuff and tasty meals in his café and to ensure that his clients have the possibility to eat, to rest and buy. His business is stable, which allows him to generate a significant income and ensure worthy living for his family. Now Tuichiboy’s children are growing and the expenses for them are increasing too. Thus, Tuichiboy wants to increase his business to earn more money in order to cover his children's expenses. With this purpose, he requests 7500 Somoni to expand his café. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Tumenjargal

texts.en:
Tumenjargal N. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a house in Uvs province in western Mongolia. He and his family have been living in their home for 3 years after moving from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His oldest son attends a local elementary school while his youngest daughter goes to a kindergarten.

Tumenjargal currently operates a bakery production business in a rented workshop with the help of his wife. Tumenjargal is a responsible for all works related with sales and distribution while his wife works as the lead pastry-cook in their bakery shop. They started this business in 2008 by establishing their own Bayanbulag bakery shop and have quickly found success with their business.

Today, Tumenjargal's bakery shop has 5 workers and produces almost 20 different types of breads and baked pastry. Under the "LUNCH" program, implemented by Mongolian Government, he has made contracts with local schools, kindergartens and organizations and permanently supplies his products to 56 organizations. He pays 80,000 MNT (60 USD) in rent every month. He is a hard working, open minded man who is focused on the future growth of his business. He says “I want to expand my business and to have my own workplace in the future”.  He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT (1508 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of raw materials such as floor, sugar etc., at wholesale price for his bakery business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of raw materials.

loans.name: Gantuul

texts.en:
Gantuul G. is 28 years old and lives with her husband and 9-year-old daughter in the Hentiy province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter, Hongorzul, attends a local kindergarten while her husband, Batzorig, is a driver and operates a transportation service using his mini-truck in their town. He transports a variety of groceries and construction products during summer months and coal and firewood in the winter months.

Gantuul sells a variety of clothing items in a rented stall at the local market. She started her clothing business in 2008 and has built a stable operation. Her business is located in a popular spot in the market and her customer base includes residents of her province.

Gantuul’s and her husband's earnings together have enabled them to build a new fence around their house and garage. Gantuul is a hardworking, honest and helpful woman who says: "I am proud of my business; it's nice to see the satisfaction of my customers after they purchase my clothes; therefore, my business provides positive energy to my customers."

Gantuul is requesting a 2,375,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes and uniforms for starting the new academic year.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and uniforms

Cuong has been a member of SEDA for four years and used her loans to pay school fees. Consequently, her children are obtaining a good education.

Currently, one of Cuong’s children is going to go to university and so she wants to obtain a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy some necessary equipment for him.

loans.use: To buy some educational equipment for her son

loans.name: Orgil

texts.en:
Orgil A. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and five year old daughter in Hentiy province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in a relations yard. His wife works as a bond teller in a company. Orgil currently operates a taxi service in his town. He started driving a taxi in 2008 and has found success. He has used his earnings to stabilize his family's financial situation and improve their quality of life. His daily revenue is a between 18,000 and 25,000 MNT (13-19 USD)and daily business expense is around 9,000 MNT (7 USD). 

For the future, he hopes to continue his business' stable operation and to purchase new car for his business. He is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT (980 USD)loan to purchase auto-parts and to make repairs to his car.

loans.use: To purchase auto-parts and to make repairs to his car

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing construction services to local community members. Rheza has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month for these activities.

Rheza is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Rheza from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Quyet

texts.en: Quyet T. P. is 54 years old. She has a mechanical workshop that makes steel windows and doors, as ordered by clients. Her business started in 2006  when she received her first loan, which was in the amount of 2,204,000 VND. Every month she gets approximately $210 profit from her business. She is developing  her workshop more so she needs a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy steel and iron materials.

loans.use: to buy steels and  iron as material .

loans.name: Meerinsa's Group

texts.en:
Meerinsa A. is the leader of this group. She is 36 years old and divorced. She has an eight-year-old daughter who goes to school.  A year ago, with the initial investment of 5,000 KGS, Meerinsa started her own business. She is engaged in the wholesale trade of home products. In this way she earns around $170 per month.  With money received from the loan, Meerinsa wants to purchase a variety of goods to resell, such as pillows, napkins, toiletries, etc. In the future she wants to expand her business and then save money to purchase a vehicle.

Gulnara A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 47 years old and married. She has three sons and two daughters. Her two older sons are engaged in cattle breeding and the other children are at school.  Gulnara and her husband started to breed cattle fifteen years ago. Selling some cattle after fattening they average about $43 per month. Gulnara also cultivates and sells raspberries for income.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a bull in order to resell it at a higher price after fattening.
 
Ysakbai A., 63, is married. He has a daughter and two sons, all of whom are at school.  Ysakbai works in a barber shop and his wife is a librarian. Ysakbai hopes to obtain the loan because he needs money to start repairing his house. In the future, he dreams of opening his own barber shop. 

Damirbek T., 23, is married. He is an electrician and his wife works as a nurse in the hospital. Four years ago, with the initial investment of 5,000 KGS, he started to breed cattle. Selling some farm animals after fattening he makes around $85 per month. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase a bull for breeding, and some part of the loan he will use to celebrate his wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase home products to resell
