loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en:
Tserendolgor S. is a 44-year old married woman with four children. She and her family live together in a ger (a traditional Mongolian housing tent) in Uvurhangai province of central Mongolia. Her oldest child attends the university. Her two daughters study at a local secondary school. Both her husband and their youngest child are disabled and stay at home. 

Tserendolgor is a seamstress who sews a variety of clothes. She began her business in 2000 by selling a variety of consumer goods in a rented stall at the local market. In the beginning, she operated her sewing business in her home, taking orders from people to supplement her income. She has now moved her sewing business to her rented stall, which gives her greater access to more customers. Over the years of operation, she has gained a lot of experience as a seamstress. Her business is in a popular spot in the market where there are no competitors around. Tserendolgor hopes to continue to make her business a stable operation. She wants to have her own workplace in the future and says "I am trying best to expand my business." 

Tserendolgor is a gentle and hard working woman and is requesting a 600,000 MNT (452 USD) loan to purchase a variety of fabrics and silks from Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of fabrics

loans.name: Luz María

texts.es:
La Señora Luz Maria D. es socia del banco comunal Vegaspamba, vive en la comunidad que lleva el mismo nombre, esta comunidad se encuentra a 45 min  de la ciudad de Cuenca, su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura.

Nuestra socia tiene de 40 años, es casada y tiene 8 hijos de 21, 20, 16, 13, 8, 7 5 y 1 año de edad, su primera y tercera de sus hijas se dedican a trabajar y son quienes ayudan a la economía de la casa, su segunda hija ayuda al trabajo de la casa al igual que su cuarto hijo, sus hijos de 8, 7 y 5 años estudian en una escuelita de la comunidad. Su esposo trabaja en el área de la construcción ya que es maestro albañil y gracias al trabajo conyugal y a las habilidades de su esposo como albañil hace poco tiempo han logrado construir su casa propia.

Doña Luz se dedica a la elaboración de sogas hace 10 años ya que su mamá le ha enseñado esta labor desde muy pequeña, como pasa en la casa también se dedica a la cría de gallinas y cuyes  que los vende en su comunidad o también son para el consumo de su hogar.
 
Este es el quinto crédito que realiza en la banca comunal, los anteriores le han beneficiado en la construcción de su casa, su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra piola para la elaboración de sus sogas.
 
Su meta es  terminar su casa ya que aun le hacen falta muchos detalles.
texts.en:
Mrs. Luz Maria D. is a member of the Vegaspamba communal bank. She lives in Vegaspamba which is located 45 minutes from the city of Cuenca. Its residents raise farm animals and are farmers. She is 40 years old, married and has 8 children who are 21, 20, 16, 13, 8, 7, 5 and 1 year of age. Her first and third daughters work and help support the household. Her second daughter as well as her fourth son help with housework. The 8, 7 and 5 year-olds go the local school. Her husband works in constrution since he’s a master bricklayer. Thanks to the couple’s work and her husband’s skills as a bricklayer they managed to build their own house a short while ago. Luz has made ropes for the past 10 years. Her mother taught her how when she was still a little girl. Since she spends her time at home, she also raises chickens and guinea pigs that she sells in her community or that are consumed in the home. This is the 5th loan she’s had in the communal bank. The previous ones were used to build the house. The new loan will be to buy cords that will be used to make the ropes. Her goal is to finish building her house because it still needs a few finishing touches.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cord for rope making.

loans.name: Flor Ermencia

texts.es:
La Señora Flor Ermencia D. es socia del banco comunal Vegaspamba. Vive en la comunidad que lleva el mismo nombre, esta comunidad se encuentra a 45 min de la ciudad de Cuenca, su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura.

La Señora Flor con su trabajo está sacando adelante a su familia, se dedica a la agricultura, vende  sus verduras hace 6 años un mercado de la ciudad, también compra a otros proveedores para tener un gran surtido de productos en su negocio, los días feriados sale al mercado con sus productos desde las 3 a.m. hasta que termine la venta, los demás de días sale a vender desde las 4 a.m.

Doña Flor tiene 36 años, está separada hace 5 años y tiene 6 hijos de 17, 13, 10, 8, 7 y 6 años de edad, su primera hija trabaja y es quien le ayuda económicamente, su segunda hija estudia en un colegio de la ciudad y sus últimos cuatro hijos estudian en la escuela. No tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando.
 
Se encuentra en su sexto ciclo y los créditos le han  beneficiado en su trabajo, el crédito que recibe de la fundación Espoir lo va a invertir en la compra de más verduras para la venta.
 
Su meta es crecer más en su negocio para poder ofrecerle una mejor educación y alimentación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Flor Ermencia D. is a member of the Vegaspamba communal bank. She lives in Vegaspamba which is located 45 minutes from the city of Cuenca. Its residents raise farm animals and are farmers. Flor has raised her family through her work. She is a farmer and has sold her vegetables for the last 6 years in a local municipal market. She also buys from other suppliers in order to have a varied stock on hand. On feast days she goes to the market with her goods from 3am until she sells out. The rest of the days she starts selling at 4am. Flor is 36 years old, separated for the last 5 years and has 6 children who are 17, 13, 10, 8, 7 and 6 years of age. Her oldest daughter works and helps her economically. Her second daugther goes to school in the city and her youngest four are in the local school. She does not own a home, she rents. This is her 6th loan cycle. The loans have benefited her work. The loan she gets from Fundación Espoir will be used to buy vegetables to sell. Her goal is to grow more in her business so that she can offer a better education and nourishment to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables.

loans.name: Tsetsgee

texts.en:
Tsetsgee T. is a 50-year old married woman who lives with her family in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia in their own ger (a traditional nomadic housing tent). Her two children are students and they live and study in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband works as a private businessman. 

Tsetsgee currently operates a meat retailing business in her town. She began her business in 1995 after moving from the micro province and has gained much experience in it. She buys a large amount of meat from countryside at wholesale prices, and she sells the meat at retail prices. She is a very accurate, friendly, and intelligent woman who has a great business mind. She is optimistic about the future and has been making plans to enlarge her business. She says, "My children are growing up so I want to focus on expanding my business and to have my own workplace." Tsetsgee is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a new truck for her son.

loans.use: To purchase a new truck

loans.name: Zoila Mercedes

texts.es:
La Señora Zoila Mercedes F. es socia del banco comunal Vegaspamba. Vive en la comunidad que lleva el mismo nombre, esta comunidad se encuentra a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Cuenca, su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura.
 
Nuestra socia tiene 32 años, vive en unión libre y  tiene 3 hijos  de 8, 6 y 4 años de edad, todos sus hijos estudian en una escuela de la comunidad. Su esposo es de profesión albañil, no tienen casa propia, viven en la escuela donde trabajan.

Doña Zoila trabaja como conserje de la escuela hace 3 años en donde tiene una tienda, también se dedica a la cría de pollos, cuyes y chanchos a los que los vende en su comunidad.
 
Es nuestra socia hace 2 años y todos los créditos le han beneficiado, este credito lo va ha invertir en la compra de productos para su tienda.

Su meta es llegar a tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Zoila Mercedes F. is a member of the Vegaspamba communal bank. She lives in Vegaspamba which is located 45 minutes from the city of Cuenca. Its residents raise farm animals and are farmers. She is 32 years old, has a life partner and three children who are 8, 6, and 4 years of age. All her children go to the local school. Her husband is a bricklayer. She does not own her house; they live in the school where they work. Zoila has been employed for the last three years as a caretaker at a school. She also raises chickens, guinea pigs and pigs that she sells in her community. She has been a member for two years and all the loans have benefited her. This loan will be used buy stock items for her store. Her goal is to own a home of her own someday.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Tumurbat

texts.en:
Tumurbat P. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Uvurhangai province in Mongolia. He and his family have been living in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, for the past ten years. His older daughter attends a local secondary school. 

Tumurbat operates a shoe repairing business in his town, with the help of his wife. He repairs boots and shoes in a local main market of his town. He purchases a large amount of raw materials at a time from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, that can used for two to three months in his business. He is a very hard working man and says, "I try my best to expand my business and to save money for the future." 

He is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT ($1350) loan in order to purchase more raw materials at wholesale prices, such as leather, fabric, heels and glue.

loans.name: Sahtagan

texts.en:
Sahtagan M., 37, lives with his wife and four children in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in Bayan-Ulgiy Province in western Mongolia. His wife is currently unemployed, while three of their children attend a local secondary school and his youngest son goes to a local kindergarten.

Sahtagan has operated a transportation service using his truck since 2000, and his earnings from this successful enterprise enabled him to purchase a big new Russian truck called the Zil-130 with a truck trailer in 2009. He hopes to continue making progress with his business and says, " My truck trailer is old, so I need to purchase a new one." Sahtagan is now requesting a 3,000,000 MNT (2249 USD) loan to increase his working capital before coal prices become high in anticipation of winter.

loans.use: To buy more coal

texts.en:

He is working hard to expand his company although he is still struggling to maintain his business. Dugersuren is a modest person who is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT ($3,000 )to purchase printing equipment in order to increase his work output.

loans.name: Enkhjargal

texts.en: Mr Enkhjargal T. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children ages 1, 9, and 18 in a suburb of Darkhan (the second largest city in Mongolia). He has been running a taxi business since 2008. Before 2008 he used to make noodles and sell them in the local market. But he had to close the business because it had a too many competitors and he could not make a decent income. Now his taxi business is the only source of family income. His wife is looking after the baby. His eldest son Dorjrencen,18 studies in an auto mechanic’s course and graduates this December. His other son, Buyandorj, age 9 attends a local public school. Mr Enkhjargal is planning to sell his old car and buy another second hand one because of the safety regulations of the  transportation authority. The loan he is requesting will be used to replace his old car for newer second hand one in better condition.

loans.use: To replace his old car with newer second hand one in better condition

loans.name: Norov

texts.en: Norov T. is 62 years old and lives with her daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Norov's hospital was established in 1999  specializing in the treatment of venereal  disease- infections that are acquired and transmitted by sexual contact.  She is a hard working woman who is always looking for ways to increase her earnings. She hopes to one day have the  possibility of opening a big new hospital.  She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT (2998 USD) loan to purchase medical equipment and tools for her hospital.

loans.name: Dolgormaa

texts.en:
Dolgormaa D. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in a rented apartment owned by the 016th squad in the Tuv province in central Mongolia. Her husband works as a sergeant at the 016th Army squad and his monthly salary is 330,000 MNT (247 USD). Dolgormaa worked at Gobi Co. Ltd from 2001-2003 and at a knitting manufacturer in Ulaanbaatar as a wool knitter from 2008 to 2009.  

She started her business operation in March of 2010 after purchasing two new knitting sewing machines. She hires two employees for her sewing business. She purchases her raw materials from Gobi and Goyo Companies and produces her products. She usually sells her products at wholesale places. She is a hardworking and open-minded person and says "I will expand my business and become even more successful." Dolgormaa is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT (2998 USD) loan to purchase materials and a sewing machine that can be used to help make high-quality wool knitted products.

texts.en:

Javzanjav operates a small canteen in her town with the help of her husband. They began their business in 2000 in their yard, where they cooked a variety of meals for the local community. 

She hopes to use her business earnings to provide for her family and to build a winter house in the future. She is a modest, helpful and hardworking woman and is requesting a 500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to both purchase a variety of inventory for her cooking as well as to repair her house and fence.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of inventory

loans.name: Oyun-Erdene

texts.en:
Oyun-Erdene D. is 24 years old and lives with her husband and son in their own apartment in the Darhan-Uul province in northern Mongolia. She also takes care of her mother and younger brother since her parents are divorced. Her husband works as a chef in a local fast-food restaurant.

Oyun-Erdene started her clothing retailing business in 2003 at a stall outside of Darhan -- the local biggest market -- with the working capital of 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT), or about $750. She was able to rent a stall in Darhan Nomin after two years of successful business operation. By this time, her working capital reached 2,000,000 MNT (or about $1,500). 

Oyun-Erdene is a very open-minded and sociable woman and is well-known by her customers. For the future, she says, " I am trying my best to afford my younger brother's tuition fee and I would like to have another stall to expand my business and increase my sales." 

She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to import more clothing items for 2,000,000 MNT and a large number of shoes at 2,000,000 MNT from Ereen, a border city of China, for her business.

loans.use: To import more clothing

loans.name: Dulmaa

texts.en:
Dulmaa B. is a widow who lives with her 21-year-old son, her daughter-in-law and her grandchild in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Dulmaa receives a government retirement pension and her health is good. Dulmaa used to sell various kinds of products in the street, but has been operating a small grocery shop in her yard since 2001. She started a dairy-product retail business in her town at the local market in 2007. 

She goes to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to sell her dairy products during the cold season. She travels through the countryside to collect and prepare her dairy products. She is planning to continue her business and wants to help pay for her grandchild's university education when the time comes. 

Dulmaa is requesting a 4,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase and preserve a large amount of dairy products now so that she can sell them for a larger profit in the winter.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products

loans.name: Damiran

texts.en:
Damiran N., age 51, lives with his wife and four sons, whose ages range from 21 to 28, in their own traditional housing tent called a ger in Uvs province, western Mongolia. All of his sons help him out with his business. The youngest son is a student while his wife works as a saleswoman in their town. 

He began his food retailing business in 2006 and it is now considered the biggest store in his local area. His wife is responsible for managing the food store while Damiran operates a transportation business in his town. His personality is not so polite, but he seems to be good at calculating and estimating and is a responsible person. 

He wants to expand his own food store and manage it sustainably. Damiran is requesting a 4,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase food products at wholesale prices from Tashkent, the border city of China, in order to increase his business line.

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Jinny

texts.en: Jinny R. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Jinny is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jinny sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Jinny has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Jinny joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jinny is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Jinny from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Mukisa Women's Group Lugazi

texts.en:
It pays to be cordial, placid, and resolute, and to always have resources in reserve to deal with the unexpected when doing business. This is the perspective that 46-year-old N. Teddy has been laying to heart the last eight years running her pub and pork-selling businesses in Namataba-Lugazi. N. belongs to the Mukisa women’s group - Lugazi. 

N. has succeeded in making profitable use of her time running this business that she began with the help of her husband. Savings from her pub business rendered countenance to her in getting her on her feet. In a week she makes profits that add up to 450,000 shillings. With this loan she wants to buy more crates of both hard and soft drinks for her business and also to buy pigs to reduce the costs she incurs buying pork from butcher shops.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of hard and soft drinks for her pub and to buy pigs.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz  is from the village of Culpan, Aloran, Mis. Occ. . She is 31 years old. Luz  is married and has two very young children. To make a living, Luz owns  & operates a general store (Sari-sari store). 

Luz has been in this business for about 2 years  and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for this activity. In 2008, Luz  joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz  has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC amounting to PHP 10,000. Luz is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used for her house repair project. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Luz from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Dinara

texts.en:
Dinara T. lives in the Kyrgyz southern city Osh. She is 44, married, and has four children.  In 2006, when her husband lost his job, she became the only bread-winner for her children. But her salary didn’t meet all the expenses of her family and for this reason, Dinara decided to begin her sales business.  Having been a very persistent person, she concentrated all her efforts and achieved success. 

Dinara managed to obtain a small shop at the local market, which had a wide assortment of women's clothes.  Her loyal customers – mostly school teachers, highly appreciate the good quality of Dinara's goods and the very attentive attitude of the shopkeeper to every client. 

In June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the city of Osh, Dinara lost her business. Her shop was robbed and looted. 

However, Dinara isn't giving up and is ready to resume her lost business and continue to work. For this very reason, Dinara is applying for a loan of 135,000 KGS, which she needs to restart her activity. She plans to purchase more women’s clothes to resell at the local market. Dinara believes that her favorite city Osh will certainly rise from the ashes and become a prosperous one. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase women's clothes for resale

loans.name: Byambatsogt

texts.en:
Byambatsogt M. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and five children in Tosontsengel, a commune of Zavhan province in Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest three children, ages 12, 9 and 6, all attend a local school and his younger two children stay at home. His wife, Altantuya, operates a clothes-making business in her home where she sews traditional Mongolian-style clothing. 

Byambatsogt, himself, operates  two different kinds of business depending on the season. In the summer months, he operates a vegetable-growing business and in the winter months, he works as a fireman in the school. His wife has been sewing a variety of traditional clothes for three years. She has used her earnings to purchase more fabrics to sew more clothes. And also her earnings have enabled her to buy school supplies for her children. 

Byambatsogt and his wife both are very hardworking persons and they have used their earnings to buy a fenced-in plot of land. He says, "My wife and I both work very hard to order to provide a healthy and wealthy lifestyle for our children." He is requesting a 200,000 MNT loan both to purchase a wood timbers for his fence door and to buy some fabrics for his wife's sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase  wood timber and fabrics for his wife's business

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina T. is a 33-year-old charcoal dealer in Jomvu, Mombasa. Penina is married to William who also supports the family with his income. They are blessed with four children. Peninah has been in this business for the last four years and she is doing great. 

This is Penina’s first loan from KADET LTD and she plans to purchase more sacks of charcoal for her business and use the anticipated profit to open a green grocery.

She hopes to be successful in both her businesses and expand more.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal for her business

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad V. is from the village of Burgos. She is 57 years old. Natividad is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Natividad owns & operates a business selling vegetables in the market. Natividad has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Natividad joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Natividad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Natividad is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Natividad from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine N. is 36 years old. She is single and has 10 dependants. Her business is located at Mwingi in a very busy market and is served by the Thika Branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. She sells charcoal in the residential area, a business she has done for the last 10 years. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is financial constraints, not being able to buy her products at wholesale. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 10,000 to buy more charcoal to expand her business and be able to serve more customers. In the future, she hopes to grow her business and be able to buy at wholesale. She also hopes to give her children a good education. She describes herself as hardworking, innovative, patient and quiet.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Mucee

texts.en:
Mucee N. is a 36-year-old married man and a father of three children. He operates a retail shop that has been in existence for the past three years now. The business is situated in Central Malindi town where it serves the town dwellers and passersby. 

The businessman was introduced to KADET LIMITED by another client of the company and this is the second time that he is taking a loan from the KADET LTD. The loan amounts to Kshs. 38,000 and Mr. Mucee is planning to use it to add stock to his shop. Mucee wishes to use the anticipated profit from the business continue educating his children, keep on looking after his family and to further expand his business so as to one day own a chain of shops or even to own a well established supermarket.

loans.use: To add stock to his retail shop

loans.name: Munhtugs

texts.en: Munhtugs T. is 33 years old and lives with her husband and infant daughter in their ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Zavhan province of Mongolia. Her husband, Narantungalag, operates an auto repair center in his town with the help of his father to supplement his family income. Munhtugs owns and operates a grocery store with the help of her mother. She began her business in 2006 with a small shop and since then she has managed to expand her shop into a supermarket, the only one in her town. Her supermarket is a self-service store offering a wide variety of food and household merchandise in the local community. Over years of successful operation, also her revenues and profits have risen and she has built a stable operation. She is a very hardworking and open minded person who wants to keep growing her business in the future. Munhtugs is requesting a 400,000 MNT (300 USD)loan in order to purchase a large amount of inventory from Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia for her supermarket.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of inventory

loans.name: Roxanne

texts.en:
Roxanne L. is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 26 years old. Roxanne is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Roxanne owns & operates a business providing tri-sikad services to local community members. Her husband is the driver. Roxanne has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Roxanne joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roxanne is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Roxanne from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is from the village of Purok 2 Bolibol, Oroquieta City . She is 49 years old. Gloria  is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Gloria  owns  & operates a retail store (Sari-sari store). Gloria has been in this business for about 10 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for this activity.

 In 2007, Gloria  joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria  has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC amounting to PHP 6,000. Gloria  is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for her Sari-Sari Store. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Gloria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional Capital for her retail business (SariSari Store)

loans.name: Nyamaahuu

texts.en:
Nyamaahuu D. is a 54-year-old widow who lives with her two adult sons in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Chingeltey district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her older son, Zol, is at a Science and Medical University while her younger son, Zolhuu, works as an accountant in a Petrovis company.  

Nyamaahuu worked for a barber and beauty training center as a teacher between 1991-2000. She started to operate a hair salon in the Urt-Tsagaan trade center in Ulaanbaatar in 2000. She cuts both men's and women's hair. In addition, she also works as a part-time teacher in a Londa hair salon to supplement her  income. For the future, she plans to open her own hair salon training center. 

Nyamaahuu is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan in order to redecorate her hair salon into one suitable for a training center.

loans.use: To refurbish her hair salon

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma L. is 32 years old, married and has four school-aged children. She is from the village of Barangay 4 in the municipality of Talakag, Bukidnon province on the Mindanao islands. Alma provides trisikad (a bicycle with sidecar for two) services to local community members with her husband as the driver. Alma has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010 Alma joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Alma is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase equipment needed to maintain service. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase equipment needed to maintain service

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry K. is a 23-year-old man who is married and has one child who is now three years old. Henry has been in the fishing business for the past year now. He works in Sita, Malindi, and his clients are mostly from that area.

This is the first time Henry is asking for a loan from KADET after being introduced to the company by a credit officer who is a staff member there. The loan he wants amounts to 10,000 KES, and he plans to use some of it to buy more fishing equipment so as to strengthen his business and use the rest to educate his son who is going to nursery school and to sustain his young family. He wants his business to become well-established and have its own premises.

loans.use: To buy more fishing equipment and pay for his son's nursery school

loans.name: Kaneez's Group

texts.en:
Kaneez is the mother of three daughters and a son. Her eldest daughter is a seamstress and sews clothes for neighborhood clients. Her son works in a government sector and does sewing work part-time. Her younger daughters are in fifth and second standards. Kaneez’s husband is a retired government officer and spends his time at home. The family lives in a small village named Hayyatabad within the city of Chichawatni. Chichawatni is famous for its agricultural industry.

Kaneez is a very helping lady by nature. She assists her daughter in completing customers’ orders with her sewing. She always supports her daughter and guides her in making new designs for dresses. Sewing has become the family business because most of its members are involved in this work.

Kaneez has applied for a loan from Asasah for her son who wants to improve his sewing business by buying an electric sewing machine that will help him work better and fulfill large orders on time. He has five years of experience in the sewing business, and Kaneez is confident that he will get good results from his business after this investment.

Kaneez is a regular client of Asasah and is in her third loan cycle. In the previous loan periods she has proved herself as a responsible client who has always paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings.

Note: In the photograph the lady who is holding a book (called the Asasah Passbook) in her hand is Kaneez.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old single man living with his parents. He is from Lebanon. For the past four years, he has made his living as a professional home painter. He operates his business by taking private projects. With his business income, he is able to help his father with the family expenses. With his requested Kiva loan of $1100, he will purchase scaffolding and purchase new tools. He hopes that these improvements will enable him to provide his services to new customers and take on more projects. 

In the future, he is planning to expand his business, take bigger projects, and build a solid professional reputation.

loans.use: purchase scaffolding and renew his tools

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca O. is from Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 41 years old and is married with five adult children. Rebecca owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Rebecca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Rosemarie D. is from the village of Burgos. She is 43 years old and is married with four school-aged children. Rosemarie owns and operates a business running a food stall, tending a canteen in the school. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rosemarie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nou

texts.en:
Nou C., 51, is married and lives with her three children in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband works in construction, making US$3 each day.

Two of Nou C.’s children are bakers and one is a garment factory worker. Nou C. is asking for a loan of US$400 to invest in her children’s bakery.

loans.use: To invest in her children's bakery

loans.name: Paul Kituli

texts.en:
Paul Kituli is a 45-year-old restaurant proprietor in Maweni, Mombasa. He is married to Monica Mwenda, who supports him in their business, and they are blessed with four children.

Paul is requesting his second loan from KADET to purchase additional foodstuffs for his restaurant. He plans to use the anticipated profit to expand his restaurant.  In the future, he hopes to expand his business and be able to satisfactorily support his family.

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstuffs for his restaurant

loans.name: Ulziijargal

texts.en:
Ulziijargal G. is a 33-year-old single man who lives with his mother in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Zavhan province of Mongolia. His mother is unemployed and helps him with his business.

Ulziijargal operates two different businesses and both are seasonal. In winter months, he operates a raw material trade while in summer months, he sells a variety of fruits in the local community. He has been operating those two businesses since 2008, and has built a stable operation.

Ulziijargal buys a large amount of bilberries and blueberries from Tosontsengel, one of the communes of Zavhan, and sells them at a stall in the market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Ulziijargal is a very hardworking man; using his earnings, he has managed to create for himself a demand deposit at the bank of 1,500,000 MNT.

Ulziijargal is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase 200kg of fruits to resell in Ulaanbaatar.

loans.use: To purchase 200kg of fruits to resell in Ulaanbaatar

loans.name: Reynalda

texts.en:
Reynalda T., 41, is married and has two school-aged children. She is from the barangay of Burgos, a part of the municipality of Naguilian in Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Reynalda runs a store from which she sells vegetables to the local community. Reynalda has been in business for over twenty years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009 Reynalda joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Reynalda successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional produce to sell. Reynalda is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be Reynalda’s third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional produce to sell

loans.name: Pegn

texts.en:
Pegn P. is 48 years old and is married with three children, two of whom are garment factory workers. They live in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than $1 USD each day, while her husband, pictured here, is a moto-taxi driver. On average, he makes $4 USD a day.

Pegn P. would like to take out a loan of $1200 USD to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting purposes

loans.name: Estela

texts.en:
Estela P. is 36 years old, married and has nine school-aged children. She is from the village of Barangay 4 in Talakag municipality, a part of the province of Bukidnon on the Mindanao islands. Estela runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she sells both food and daily use products to the local community. Estela has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2010 Estela joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Estela is requesting a loan, her first, of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Carlina

texts.en:
Carlina R. is from District II. She is 49 years old and single. To make a living, Carlina owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling siomai (a kind of dimsum). She has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Carlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to for the same purpose. This will be Carlina’s 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline N. is a 27-year-old single lady. She sells shoes in Timboni in Malindi. Her business has been in operation for the past year.

Jackline is taking her first loan of 40,000 KES from KADET to which she was introduced by another client who is a member of KADET. The lady wishes to expand her business by adding more stock in order to satisfy her ever-increasing number of clients.

Jackline hopes to grow her business so that one day she will own a well-established boutique that will serve her clients in Timboni and elsewhere.

loans.use: To add more inventory to her business

loans.name: Meziel

texts.en:
Meziel S. is 24 years old, single and has an infant. She is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag municipality in the province of Bukidnon in northern Mindanao. Meziel runs a store from which she sells rice by the kilogram to the local community. Meziel has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2010 Meziel joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Meziel is requesting her first loan from HSPFI of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional rice to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional rice to sell

loans.name: Enhgerel

texts.en:
Enhgerel S. is a 56-year old widow who lives with her daughter and son-in law in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Tuv province in Mongolia. She manages her grocery store with the help of her daughter. She has been in business since 2008. Her methods and experience have improved and grown, and the number of her clients has increased.

Initially she started in business by managing a computer game center service with working capital of a half million MNT, but now it has grown to 5,000,000 MNT (3,748 USD). Her family managed to expand their small store into a newer and bigger one with their business profit.

Enhgerel is a hard-working, modest woman who would like to keep growing her business further. She says, “I wish I could help my daughter to get a house with our business profits.” She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT (2,998 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of food to be sold in the store and increase her working capital as well.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of food for her store

loans.name: Koy

texts.en:
Koy K. is 57 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Takeo province. Since 1995, she has been making and selling brooms at the local market to earn approximately $3 of profit a day, while her husband (pictured here) works in construction. On average, he makes $4 per day. This couple is also supported by two children who are garment-factory workers. 

Koy K. is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase wood and other material to build a new wooden house. Since the old house is too old, not reliable and leaking during the rainy season, Koy K. asks for the loan to build a new house.

loans.use: To finish her construction

loans.name: Floribeth

texts.en: Floribeth S. is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old. Floribeth is separated from her spouse and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Floribeth buys and sells clothing and shoe products in the local community. Floribeth has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Floribeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Floribeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Floribeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Carmelisitacion

texts.en: Carmelisitacion A. is from the village of District II. She is 54 years old. Carmelisitacion is widowed and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Carmelisitacion provides manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Carmelisitacion has been engaged in her business for over 26 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Carmelisitacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelisitacion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Carmelisitacion is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the third loan taken out by Carmelisitacion from ASKI. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas.
