loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose A. is from the village of District II. He is 19 years old. Jose is single. To make a living, Jose operates a family member's business venture in the manufacturing sector, operating a furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Jose has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Jose is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will also be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jose from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is a 38-year-old sole proprietor shop owner and a widow in Mikindani Mombasa.

Supporting her young children, she gets help from the elder children. She lives in a family of six people. Being a member of KADET LTD, she is applying for a loan of Kshs. 40,000 which she plans to use to add more stock of goods for her retail shop. She plans to use the anticipated profit to open up a wholesale shop.

Mary K. hopes to be able to educate her children and provide them with the necessary basic needs for her family. She would also like to venture into transporting goods to Rwanda in future.

loans.use: To add more stock of retail items

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn S., 55, is married with two children living at home in the Takeo province. He and his wife make and sell piggy banks, typically making US $2 each day. This family is also supported by one child who works as a garment factory worker and makes US $2.50 per day. Sorn S. is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase a motorbike to transport piggy banks to sell at the market. 

Sorn S. was not available for the picture; that is why his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios P.'s main source of income comes from providing manicure and pedicure services in her community. She is 51 years old, widowed and has six grown-up children. She is from the village of District II. Remedios has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more materials needed for the service. This will be her third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide a manicure service

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia M.'s main source of income comes from fattening pigs for sale. She is 52 years old, married and has seven grown-up children. She is from the village of District II. Sofia has been in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Sofia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Sofia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase livestock to raise. Sofia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock to raise and sell. This will be her third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Maria Lourdes

texts.en: Maria Lourdes M. owns and operates a business making and selling specialty food products like fruit salad ice candy and steamed cake in her community. She is 26 years old, married and has four small children. They are from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. Maria Lourdes has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Maria Lourdes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Shagufta's Group

texts.en:
Shagufta is 44 years old, married to M. I., and lives in a small city in Pakistan called Chichawatni. She sells bangles to support her family financially. Her husband is a hairdresser. He operates his own barber shop in the nearby market. Due to his good services, people from other places also come to him to get his services. 

Shagufta is the mother of three sons and a daughter. Her eldest son has completed 12th grade and started working in a pharmaceutical company as a medical rep. The next to him is doing his bachelor's degree and the youngest one is in 6th standard. Her daughter is 8 years old and has not started to attend school. 

Shagufta has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to improve his business. With the loan, he will buy hair products such as hair colors, creams, conditioners and hair shampoos, to provide better quality services to his clients. Shagufta is confident that this investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s business and he will be able to increase his income. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is on her second loan cycle. She has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the picture, the lady who holds a book (an Asasah passbook) in her hand is Shagufta.

loans.use: To buy hair products for a barber shop

loans.name: Claris

texts.en: Claris K. is a 24-year-old lady who is married and has four children. She sells fish in Sita, Malindi. This lady was introduced to KADET by a friend who happens to be one of her customers. She is taking out her first loan of 5,000 Kenyan shillings and she plans to stock more fish to sell. Claris hopes to grow her business with this loan and wishes to use the anticipated profit to help educate her children. Her customers are mostly people from Sita where her business is situated.

loans.use: To buy more fish for sale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 46-year-old married man and father of 4 children whom 3 are still attending the school. After being laid off by his previous employer, he decided to open a small cafeteria in his town. He is satisfied with the decision to start his own business, because with its income, he is able to continue paying for his childrens' education. His cafeteria is known as a comfortable place by the clients who visit him to have a good time. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to renew his business tools. 
In the coming years, he is planning to expand his cafeteria to attract more customers.

loans.use: to renew his business tools

loans.name: Seteer

texts.en:
Seteer A. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. They live together in a traditional Mongolian housing tent known locally as a ger. His oldest son currently studies at a local university and his 5-year-old daughter is in kindergarten. He and his wife both receive monthly retirement benefits from the government totaling 320,000 MNT, but their main household income comes from their vegetable-trading business. 

Seteer has two fields totaling 6 hectares, where he grows a variety of vegetables, as well as a 2-hectare field for hay. Seteer started his vegetable-trading business in 2004. Due to the short growing season and long winters in Mongolia, Seteer preserves most of his vegetables through the winter and sells them in the spring when demand is high. He has an underground storage facility that he built in his yard. During the fall and winter months, he purchases vegetables from other farmers that he resells. 

Seteer is a very open-minded and hardworking person. He says, "Generally, my vegetable output is enough to cover my household consumption, however, this year's harvest was very low. Next year I plan to plant more so I will have a surplus to sell"

Seteer  is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase 3 tons of carrots and 2 tons of beets to sell.

loans.use: To purchase three tons of carrots and two tons of beets

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en: Catalina A. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old. Catalina is married and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, Catalina buys and sells dried fish in the local community. Catalina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Catalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catalina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional dried fish to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Catalina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional dried fish to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian C. is a 28-year-old supplier of eggs and mineral water in Bamburi, Mombasa. She is married to Victor Mbera, who supports her income, and together they are blessed with three children. 

Lilian has been in this business for the last two years and she has been successful.

Having been introduced to KADET LTD., she is now requesting her first loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase more trays of eggs and use the anticipated profit to start up a retail shop.

In the future, she hopes to succeed in her business through KADET LTD. loans and also improve the standard of living of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more trays of eggs

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Farzana is a resident of a small village in the city of Chichawatni called Hayatabad. Chichawatni city in Pakistan is famous for its agriculture industry.

Farzana sells bangles to financially support her family. Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He drives someone else’s rickshaw. He wants to buy his own auto rickshaw which will stop him from paying rent. In this way, his income will increase and the rickshaw will become an asset for his family as well. Farzana has applied for a loan from Asasah to financially assist her husband in this regard. She is very confident that her husband will be able to improve his business and income by investing money in purchasing his own auto rickshaw. 

Farzana is the mother of a 4-year-old daughter. She wants to give her an education so it is very necessary for her husband’s business to improve. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her third loan cycle. In previous years, she has proved herself a responsible client who has paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the picture, the lady who holds a book (an Asasah passbook) in her hand is Farzana.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Erkhembayar

texts.en:
Erkhembayar is a 26-year-old single man. He lives with his mother and younger brother in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

Before 2009, he used to run a transportation business and left it because of the tough competition. Since 2009, he has been running a small variety store and his business has been expanding since then. He managed to finish building a family house. 

In Mongolia, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. He is the only breadwinner in this family and supports his old mother and younger brother. 

Currently, he is renting this shop on two-year agreement. His future plan is to build his own small shop. The reason he is asking for this loan is to make some internal renovations to the shop and to increase his profit by adding some working capital.

loans.use: To make some internal renovations to the shop and to increase his profit by adding some working capital

loans.name: Janarbek

texts.en:
Janarbek P. is 24 years old, single and lives with his parents and siblings in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. His father works and his mother has retired and stays at home. Janarbek used to work in a XacBank in 2008, but since then, he has begun operating a retail clothing business in a rented stall at the Kos Terek local trading center. His relative works as a salesperson in his stall. 

He usually purchases his products from Erlian, a border city of China. He is a very hardworking and calculated person and hopes to have his own store one day. He is requesting a 2,500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase more clothes from Erlian so that he can offer more products to his customers.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 33-year old married man and has 3 young children. He is the main income provider for his family. He has fifteen years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 2000. He cultivates all types of vegetables and fruits depending on the season. He also uses plastic tents to grow his products and to better monitor product quality during the year. And he delivers the harvests using a small pick-up truck to the local agriculture markets in his town. He works independently in his business. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work. In the future, he is planning to purchase a bigger pick-up truck to further expand his business into other areas.

loans.use: purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Fidela

texts.en: Fidela A. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old. Fidela is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Fidela butchers and sells pork in the market. Fidela has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Fidela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fidela is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Fidela from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence O. is 40 years old, married to Samuel and they have four children. They live in Katito town where Samuel has a taxi business to help with the upkeep of the family. Florence sells a local delicacy made out of wheat flour locally known as mandazi (a donut-like pastry). She is applying for her third loan from KADET to add more stock to her business including buying wheat flour and cooking oil. This will enable her to cook enough food to sell. Her customers normally consist of passersby in her neighborhood and the local hotels too. Her monthly income adds up to 10,000 Kenyan shillings per month. She is planning to use the profits to pay school fees for her school-going children. She hopes to see her business expand and to open up a hotel (restaurant) in the future.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil and flour to enable her to cook enough food for her clients

loans.name: David

texts.en:
On the strength of his principled work ethic, 30-year-old David  O. has not by an inch fallen out of step with his business aspirations and goals. For the last seven years, this sturdy-looking gentleman has profoundly worked hard to gain a niche for his agricultural cash crop business in Kayunga.  

He has been, for the most part, dealing in coffee, maize and tomatoes. David, an amiable and approachable father of three, says he began as a cattle herdsman and was also into cattle sales before he ventured into his current business. In a month, he makes 280,000 shillings. With this loan, he is bent on buying more sacks of coffee, maize and some tomatoes for resale, the objective being to improve the financial prospects of his business.

loans.use: The purchase of more sacks of coffee, maize and tomatoes to resell

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna A. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 48 years old. Lorna is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna buys and sells firewood in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional firewood to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Lorna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional firewood to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce K. is a 42-year-old married lady and a mother of two children. She sells second-hand clothes to Malindi town dwellers and this is where her business is situated. This is the third time that Joyce is taking a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from KADET LTD. She plans to use the money to expand her four-year-old business by increasing the stock that it already has.

The lady was introduced to KADET LIMITED by another client who is already a member of KADET LTD. She wishes to use the anticipated profit from her business to help educate her children and further expand her ever-growing business by opening a permanent boutique.

loans.use: To  purchase more stock of clothes

loans.name: Hay

texts.en: Hay N. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and three young children in Takeo province. Since 2004, she has been selling vegetables at the local market to earn a profit, typically making $3 USD per day. Her husband, pictured here, makes and sells piggy banks. On average, he earns $2 USD per day. Hay N. is asking for a loan of $1,200 USD to purchase a motorbike to transport the piggy banks to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport goods to market

loans.name: Sankaire Ole

texts.en:
Sankaire Ole I. is 37 years old. He is married to Evaline Njambi Sankaire and the father of two children. 

Sankaire is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land. He has been farming for the last 10 years.

He learned about KADET LTD from marketing awareness done by KADET LTD staff in his area. This will be his fourth loan. He is planning to spend the 24,000 KES loan on maize farming. His maize has proved to be doing very well due to fertile lands in the area and adequate rainfall. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to hire more land for farming to increase his maize production. 

His future dream is to practice large-scale maize farming. 

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: Maize farming

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
Herminia P. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 50 years old. Herminia is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Herminia owns & operates a business buying and selling used-clothing in the local community. Herminia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Herminia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Herminia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Herminia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John O. is 43 years old and married to Millicent Adhiambo. They have six children who are all in school. They live in Migori town.

John sells second-hand clothes and is applying for his second loan from KADET LTD after completing repayment of the first loan. His major need right now is to get more bales of second-hand clothes to add to his stock as the previous one is running out due to the great demands of his clients. His business is doing well and he earns an income of Kshs 20,000 per month. He plans to use the profits to buy a motorcycle and probably diversify into that business.

His hope is to expand and have a stable business.

loans.use: Buy more clothes to add to his stock

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en: Maureen K. lives in the Mulago neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (relatives).  Maureen has a business selling African attire (bitenge). She has been doing this for a long time and works 6 days out of every week. Maureen sells her products door-to-door and at retail only. Maureen has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of African attire. She also generates additional income through selling locally made ghee (clarified butter). The main business challenge for Maureen includes seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are constructing her own house and getting a permanent business premise.   Maureen lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and medication.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of clothing (African attire)

loans.name: Ruhandagazi Bakyara Twimukye, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
N. Annet, 42, is married with a family of four children and has been operating a retail shop at Ruhandagazi trading centre, Bushenyi for over four years. Here she sells a variety of products like sugar, salt, soft drinks, cooking oil and much more general merchandise. She does this business alongside her other farming practices that include growing a variety of food crops like bananas commonly grown in the area. Her main drawback is that she has a limited variety of products in her shop and cannot satisfy her customer's demands. Therefore she is looking forward to increasing her stock when she gets this loan. She will be fully stocked. This will help her earn more revenue to sustain her daily life needs and further educate her children. 
She belongs to the Ruhandagazi Bakyara Twimukye group whose members insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock like sugar, salt, soft drinks, cooking oil and much more general merchandise.

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: Narantuya L. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two sons. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her son attends a local secondary school. Her husband runs a taxi service to supplement the family income and helps with Narantuya's business. She has been operating a small grocery shop near her home since 1999. She provides a variety of food products to her customers. For the near future, she plans to finish their own rental house and warm garage, which are in the middle of construction process. She is an honest and hardworking person who says, " I'll be relieve after finishing to build our house." Her business progress and earnings have enabled her to greatly improve her family's quality of life. Narantuya is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to install a plumbing system for her warm garage.

loans.use: To install a plumbing system for her warm garage

loans.name: Virgenia

texts.en:
Virgenia M. is from the village of San Juan, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 55 years old. Virgenia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Virgenia owns & operates a business selling specialty food products in the local community. Virgenia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virgenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgenia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Virgenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Abraham Kinyanjui

texts.en:
Abraham runs a shoeshine stall and sells juice, biscuits and sweets on the side in Naivasha town.  He is 38 years and married to Mary Wanjiru. They have three children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to buy shoe polish in different colors and shoe dye, and add to his stock of biscuits, sweets and juice drinks.

Abraham hopes to expand his retail business and open a shop.

loans.use: To buy shoe polish, shoe dye, biscuits, sweets and juice.

loans.name: Cheang

texts.en: Cheang K., 36, is married and lives with her husband in the TaK. province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$1.50 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Cheang K. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1200 to make a new investment. Since farming doesn't provide enough money to raise her family, she would like to use the loan from CREDIT to run a hairdressing shop. She believes that this new business will allow her family to earnmore money.

loans.use: To open a hairdressing shop.

loans.name: Jonathan Kinkiri

texts.en:
Jonathan has been in livestock farming for thirteen years now.  He is 38 years old, married to Moton Ole L. and they have three children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy more animals to raise and sell later at a profit.

Jonathan also wants to diversify and enter the transport business by buying a car which he will use as a taxi.

loans.use: To buy more animals to raise and sell later.

loans.name: Kyanyakatura Mother's Union, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
A determined and hard working K. Scovia, who is married with four children, is vibrant as she speaks of her agricultural businesses in Kizinda, Bushenyi. She belongs to Kyanyakatura Mother's Union and she owns a banana plantation and other agricultural farms that include cattle grazing and banana sales, all of which generate income for her family. These businesses earn approximately 160,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. She also sells milk from her farm to supplement her income.

Her main drawback has been lack of funding to purchase more bananas for her stalls on her plantations, and this has reduced her sales revenue. This loan will help her improve her yields in terms of banana sales and enable her to meet the customers’ high demands. She will be better able to meet the family  requirements in terms of tuition fees for her children and a provide a more self-sustaining life.

loans.use: purchase of more bananas for her business

loans.name: Umitker

texts.en:
Umitker M. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. She and her family have been living together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, at their permanent address for the past twenty-one years. Her oldest three children attend a local secondary school while her youngest son goes to the local kindergarten. 

She operates a dairy product retail business in her town at the local market. She started her business in 2003 by selling various kinds of dairy products at an indoor stall at Turlik market, one of the main markets of her town.  She purchases all of her dairy products from the countryside's herders at wholesale prices and resells them.  From now on, she plans to purchase large amounts of dried curd cheeses and melted butters at wholesale prices and resell it during the upcoming winter months when prices for those products traditionally rise. 

For the future, she hopes to open her own dairy products shop. She smiles all the time and makes people happy even though she works very hard. "I want to provide my children with a good education and also establish my own dairy shop." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more dairy products when prices for such products are cheap.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: Arleen

texts.en:
Arleen H. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 38 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Arleen buys and resells used clothing and shoe products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $88 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Arleen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ominahon's Group

texts.en:
Ominahon H. is the leader of this group. She is 50, married, and has three sons. Her husband earns his livelihood by working as a herdsman. Her younger sons help to earn money by working in the fields. This family of farmers cultivates rice and tobacco plants in an area of 3.35 hectares. This business has supported the family for sixteen years. At first it was an area of 1.7 hectares but after a number of years it was enlarged. Having gotten a profit out of this business, they have managed to obtain a car and some cattle. The purpose of this loan is to buy onion seeds to plant. Ominahon is planning to arrange her sons’ weddings and to build a new house for their future families.

Bahrinsa E. is 39 years old and married. She is the treasurer of the group. Her spouse is an agriculturist. The couple has three children who help their parents to run the business. Sixteen years ago they used to cultivate wheat, but now the family grows rice and tobacco plants. In order to get a good harvest, lands should be carefully worked. That’s why Bahrinsa needs a loan. In the future she wants to build a new house for her son.

Baktybek K. is 29 years old and a bachelor. He is a farmer, and together with his father and sisters they run their farming business. Now they are cultivating an area of 2.7 hectares. Earnings have allowed him to make house repairs. Baktybek’s aim for getting a loan is to buy a ton of rice for future planting. He is planning to marry in the near future. 

Kumura P. is 45 years old and married. She and her husband, whose profession is farming, have two grown up children. Her son is an agriculturist. The family business is based on farming. They grow rice on a five hectare area and cucumbers on an area of 0.25 hectares. They have managed to obtain a tractor and some cattle. In order to lighten the work while harvesting, the family needs to obtain a mini-combine. For this reason they need a loan. In the future, Kumura wants to increase their stock of cattle, arrange her son’s wedding and build him a house.    

    --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase onion seeds

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda is from the village of Purok 2, Bolibol, Oroquieta City. She is 49 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store. Minda is about four years into this business and earns approximately $125 a month for this activity.

In 2008, Minda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She  has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC amounting 7,000 PHP. 

Minda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used for her sari-sari store. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna B. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 42 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling food products and buying and selling vegetables in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Balikyewunya Gayaza Womens Group A-Kampala

texts.en:
Needless to say, hard work and constant revamping measures produce profitable results, especially when one is speaking from a business point of view. 

50-year-old N. Christine of Balikyewunya Gayaza women's group in Kampala can relate to the aforementioned statement, given that for the last twenty years she has successfully been presiding over her secondhand clothing sales business in Kampala. She has been able to live within her means from this business for all these years. In a way, being a widow also pushed her to work extra hard, knowing she had to raise school fees for her kids. 

Previously she was more into banana sales. It was a business that did not generate much in terms of profits, but she still managed to survive. Now, however, she wants to rejuvenate her current business with the purchase of more bales of used clothing to resell. In a week she makes about $27, a relatively low figure considering the responsibilities she has.

loans.use: The purchase of more bales of clothes for resell

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong T., 42, is married and lives with her four young children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than $1 each day, while her husband, pictured here, is a moto-taxi driver making $3 each day.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Hong T. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $1200 to purchase a trailer to attach to her husband’s motorbike. This will allow him to transport more people at one time.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Adiya

texts.en:
Adiya J. is a 64-year-old widow and lives with her 39-year-old daughter in a ger, the Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of  Mongolia. She has been operating a handmade shoes trade business in Narantuul Trade market in the city since 2003. She sells various kinds of children's boots as well as bootikin that she makes by hand. 

Adiya is a well calculated and responsible person and says, "I plan to buy a large amount of raw materials in order to increase production as well as business profits." She is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to buy raw materials in order to produce children's and men's traditional boots for the upcoming winter.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making shoes

loans.name: Maren Ole

texts.en:
For the last three years, Maren has been rearing and selling animals in Naivasha town. He is 25 years old, is married to Memosambi K., and they have one child.

Maren was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use it to buy more animals which he will rear and sell later at a profit. The Maasai people in Kenya are members of an ethnic group called Plain Nilotes; they are nomads and are identified with the act of rearing animals which they do with a passion.

Maren is planning to save most of the profit so that he can build a nice house for his family.

loans.use: To buy more animals which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: Nora R. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 41 years old and is married with one adult child. Nora owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling dried fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Nora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional dried fish to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional dried fish to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 34-year old single man from Lebanon. He has twelve years of experience working as a farmer. He has owned his own farm since 2003.  He works independently on his farm and he lives on his own.  He is specialized in cultivating lemons and potatoes on his land. And he cooperates with some markets to deliver his products. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a new farming tool to cultivate his land.  He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%.

loans.use: purchase a new farming tool to cultivate his land

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. lives in the Wandegeya neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of her aunt. Christine lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but not piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

Christine has a restaurant business and has been in this business for eight years, working six days a week. She works from her home and on a retail basis only. Her main business challenge is seasonality.

Christine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy maize flour, rice, bunches of bananas, and beans.

Christine’s goal and aspiration for her business is to construct permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize flour, rice, bunches of bananas and beans

loans.name: Tenes Ole

texts.en:
Tenes has been in livestock farming for ten years. He is 37 years old, is married to Teeka Ene T., and they have three children.

Tenes was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy ten sheep and five goats to rear and sell later at a profit.

Tenes also wants to build rental houses on his piece of land in the future, and improve his living standard with the increased income.

loans.use: To buy ten sheep and five  goats to rear and sell later

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran belongs to a small city in Pakistan called Chichawatni. She is 30 years of age and has been living in a single-room brick house in the area 44/12L since her marriage. She doesn’t have any children, so she spends most of her time in managing her household chores.

Sughran is married to M. Y. who operates a shop selling vehicles tires. He has ten years of experience in this business and he knows the ups and downs of it very well. Sughran has applied for a loan from Asasah to financially assist her husband who wants to expand his tire-selling business. With the loan, he will buy tires of different brands and for different vehicles to sell in his shop.

Sughran believes that this investment will bring a positive change in her husband’s business and he will certainly increase the income of his business. Sughran is a new loan applicant of Asasah and is hopeful that it will be a productive experience for her and for her family as well.

In the photo, Sughran is the lady who is holding a book (called her Asasah Passbook) in her hand.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy more vehicle tires to sell

loans.name: Kakunyi Ole

texts.en:
Kakunyi has been raising animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last 25 years. He is 51 years old and married to Sioyan Ene Kakunyi. They have three children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend. This will be his first loan. He plans to buy six calves, which he will sell later at a profit. Kakunyi hopes that his livestock business will grow and that profits will enable him to educate all of his children.

loans.use: To buy six calves

loans.name: Elvera

texts.en: Elvera T. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 57 years old. Elvera is married and has an adult child. To make a living, Elvera buys and sells a variety of vegetables in the local community. Elvera has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Elvera joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvera is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Elvera from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Chuon S., 30, is a professional who decorates handicrafts at home in the Takeo province. Since 2009, she has been using beads and other materials to make flowers on women's clothing to earn a living, typically making $2 each day. 

Her husband, pictured here, is a moto-taxi driver who typically makes $4 a day. This couple has two children living at home to support. Chuon S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a moto-taxi.

loans.use: To operate a moto-taxi

loans.name: Peter Ngugi

texts.en:
Peter has been in the transportation industry for a year. He is 27 years old and married to Mary Wangare. They have one child.

He was introduced to KADET LTD. by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to set up a milk shop, which he will give to his wife to operate.

Peter hopes to grow both businesses but mainly focus on the milk shop, making it a large supplier of milk around the town of Naivasha.

loans.use: To set up a milk shop for his wife

loans.name: Sarange

texts.en:
Sarange has operated her retail shop in Naivasha town for five years.  She is 30 years old and married to Stephen Makori. They have two children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD. by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the cash to buy sugar and rice in bulk, which she will then later sell in small quantities to her clients.

Sarange plans to expand her shop and sell a variety of goods in the future.

loans.use: To buy a 90 kg sack of sugar and a 90 kg sack of rice to sell later in small quantities

loans.name: Kakompe Ole

texts.en:
Kakompe has been practicing livestock farming in Naivasha town for 23 years. He is 58 years old and married to Kimita M.. They have three children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD. by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to buy young animals, which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

Kakompe hopes that the income from livestock farming will be able to educate all his children.

loans.use: To buy young animals which he will rear and sell later

loans.name: Teng

texts.en: Teng M., 61, is married and lives with her two children in Takeo province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$ 5 each day, while her husband stays at home and helps her. Teng M. would like to request a loan of US$ 500 to expand her grocery inventory.

loans.use: To expand grocery inventory

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis C. is a 26-year-old married man who has four children. He was introduced to KADET LTD by a staff member of KADET LTD.This is his first loan with KADET LTD.

He operates a fishing business, and he has been in this business for the past five years now. Francis plans to use his loan of Kshs 5,000 to buy fishing nets and to boost his wife’s food kiosk.

His customers are mainly Malindi town dwellers and some of the hotels operating nearby. He hopes to use the anticipated profit to grow his fishing business into large-scale fishing venture and later expand into multiple businesses.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and expand his wife's food kiosk

loans.name: Gnel

texts.en: Gnel N. is 43 years old and sells fruit in Takeo province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$ 5 every day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and makes US$ 2.50 a day. This couple has five children; two are students and two others are garment factory workers. Gnel N. is asking for a loan of US$ 800 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer for her husband to operate a moto-taxi service.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer

loans.name: Mary Wanjiru

texts.en:
Mary has operated her food stall in Naivasha town for the last 10 years.  She is 32 years old, married to Peter Koigi, and they have two children.

She has been looking for capital to open up a clothes shop and her friend directed her to KADET LTD.  This will be her first loan.

Mary hopes to grow both business and to be able to build a family house through profits saved.

loans.use: To open a clothes shop

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita E., 46 years old, is married with two children and is a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) partner Microfinance Institution of KIVA in the Philippines. She joined ASHI in 1995 and today she is one of the many loyal and active members of the institution.

 As a member, she is known for being a disciplined and responsible person especially when it comes to helping other members. The primary source of income of her family is farming. The family works hand in hand in tilling their land and planting rice and vegetables. Profit from this business helps the couple in paying the school expenses of their daughter and son. They are able to provide for the daily needs of the family.

 It is rice-planting season again, and that is why she is applying for a loan of Php.30,000 for land preparation. The couple will buy vegetable seeds, sacks of organic fertilizers, pesticides and pay for farm labor. Additional income from this business will be of great help for the schooling and daily expenses of the family. 

The couple wish their children to pursue a degree in college and have a stable job in the future. They also have started renovating their house and hope to complete it once they have earned profit from this business. Their goal in life is to expand their rice and vegetable farming business and establish income for their future. Merlita is thankful that ASHI and KIVA are here to support and assist them financially in fulfilling her dreams for her family.

loans.use: To buy rice and vegetable seeds, fertilizer, pesticides and pay for labor

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 45-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has 3 school-age children. He has made his living as a professional driver. He operates a van service for customers in his village as well as neighboring towns. He has been involved in this occupation for the past 15 years. His income from his taxi business is vital to the development and care of his family. Today, he is requesting to borrow $700 to perform much needed maintenance work on his taxi’s engine and body and re-paint the body. He hopes that these improvements will enable him to provide his service to more passengers. In the future, he wishes to purchase a new car so that he can continue to expand his business.

loans.use: perform much needed maintenance work on his taxi’s engine and body and re-paint the body

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel F. is from Labuyo, Tangub City. She is 39 years old. Raquel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Raquel owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal products like lotion, face powder, soap and others in the local community. Raquel has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Raquel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Raquel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Raquel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Raquel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert K. is a 44-year-old married man. He has one wife and three children. The gentleman got introduced to KADET LTD by another client who is one of the clients of KADET LTD. 

Currently, Robert operates a poultry farm where he is the sole proprietor of the business. The business is two years old and is situated in Furunzi Malindi town and the main customers are mostly nearby hotels.

This is the third time that Robert is being granted a loan from KADET LIMITED, this time in the amount of Kshs.57,000. He plans to use the loan to buy chicks for his business, to buy necessary feed for the chicks, and use the remaining  money to pay school fees for his children.

Robert wishes to use the anticipated profit coming from the business to continue educating his children and dreams that one day he may get to own a bigger and well established poultry farm as well as residential houses.

loans.use: To buy chicks to raise, feed for the chicks, and pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Condrado

texts.en:
Condrado N. is from the village of Kinangay Sur, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 52 years old. Condrado is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Condrado owns & operates transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating motorcycle transport services. Condrado has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Condrado joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Condrado has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,900 PHP from GDMPC. Condrado is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This will be the eleventh loan taken out by Condrado from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Paul Ole

texts.en:
Paul, 29 years old, has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last nine years.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use it to buy more animals which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

Paul wants to diversify his sources of income, so he plans to open a retail shop in the near future.

loans.use: To buy animals which he will rear and sell later at a profit

loans.name: Nurjamal's Group

texts.en:
Nurjamal S. is the leader of this group. She is 33 and married. Her spouse is a road organization employee. The couple has four children. The older ones are schoolboys, and the youngest goes to a kindergarten. Two years ago, Nurjamal’s mother-in-law handed her business over to her. With the received profit she was able to afford a small summer café. She earns 5000 soms per month. Nurjamal saved some money and wants to purchase a vehicle, but she doesn’t have enough money, so she hopes to obtain this loan. In winter Nurjamal wants to improve service in order to attract more customers to the café. 

Azizbek A., 29 and married. His wife has a job as a database operator in MKK “Bai Tushum”. The couple has no children yet. Azizbek earns his living by working as a taxi-driver. His earnings helped him to get a vacuum-cleaner and a DVD-player. In order to continue his taxi-driver work, Azizbek needs to do car repairs, and he has to buy two tyres. That’s why he needs a loan. In future he is planning to build a new shop. 

Orunbai S., 35, is married. In order to supplement the family income, his wife had to go work in Russia. Their three children attend school and kindergarten. Orunbai offers Xerox service; in that way he earns his living. Thanks to his hard work, he has managed to buy a computer and a TV. He also needs a printer to expand his service, and that is the purpose of this loan. In future he wants to open his own photo salon. 

Yhval B., 31 and married, is the treasurer of the group. Her husband is a cattle breeder. They are bringing up two children. Yhval is working as a specialist in FGK “Kompaniyon”. Her salary has helped her to buy an oven and a DVD-player. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a whip. In future she wants to buy a car and to expand their raspberry plantation. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a vehicle

loans.name: Rikana Ole

texts.en:
Rikana Ole N. 57 years old. He is a farmer and supports five people in his family. His spouse is Mashipei N. and they have five children. Mashipei is a housewife and she helps Rikana with his farming activity.

Rikana has been wheat farming for the last 15 years. This will be his first loan and he is planning  to spend 10,000 Kenyan shillings to buy chemicals and fertilizer and 10,000 shillings on the cost of spraying his wheat farm.

He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his farming to expand his farming activity by renting a bigger piece of land to increase his wheat production.

His hopes and dreams are that he will become a large-scale farmer owning a bigger piece of land and being financially stable to support his family.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and fertilizer and spray his wheat farm

loans.name: Delmida

texts.en: Delmida O. is from the city of Sta. Cruz, Tangub City. She is 52 years old. Delmida is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Delmida operates a pedicab transport service. Delmida has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Delmida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delmida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Delmida from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Monico

texts.en: Monico D. is from the village of Cabaruan. He is 50 years old. Monico is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Monico raises pigs for fattening and sale. Monico has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Monico joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Monico has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. Monico is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Monico from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Eid

texts.ar: يعيش عيد البالغ من العمر 56 عاماً مع زوجته في منطقة عاليه. يعمل عيد في صيد السمك منذ 1990، عشرون عاماً في هذا المجال جعلت من عيد إبن البحر، بحيث انه لا يقوى على التوقف عن صيد السمك التي تعتبر هوايته المفضلة والوحيدة. عمد عيد ولأول مرة إلى طلب قرض من المجموعة لشراء عدة جديدة لمصلحته، مثال شباك صيد ولوازمهم... زبائنه بائعي السمك بالمفرق فهو ناشط في البيع بالجملة، كما أنه في بعض الأحيان يبيع لجيرانه و أقاربة بالمفرق. من أهم المشاكل التي واجهته خلال تأسيس عمله عدم خبرة في هذا المجال، مما جعلها صعبة في البداية إلى ان اتقنها جيداً. حبه لصيد السمك، وللبحر تحديداً كانا من الأسباب الاساسية في تطور عمله. يسعى عيد إلى تطور مصلحته، و إلى شراء سفن أكبر في المستقبل القريب.
texts.en:
Eid, 56 years old, lives with his wife in the Aliaa neighborhood. Eid has been working in fishing since 1990. After 20 years of experience working on the sea has become an integrA. part of his life; fishing is his favourite and only hobby. Eid has requested a first-time loan to buy new equipment for his work, such as fishnets and other tools. Eid is an active wholesale fishmonger and his clients are retail fishmongers. He occasionally sells retail to his neighbours and relatives. One of the key problems that he faced during his business startup was a lack of experience. Although business was hard at first, he later started to excel. His love for fishing and, more specifically, for the sea were among the main reasons for developing his business. Eid seeks to develop his business and to buy bigger fishing boats in the near future.

Translated from Arabic by Rania ElMaraghy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy the necessary tools for his business

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en: Lucena C. is from the city of Labuyo, Tangub City. She is 54 years old. Lucena is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucena runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products like toothpaste, shampoo, food for snacks, sardines, noodles, etc., in the local community. Lucena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Lucena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lucena is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Lucena from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sintet Ole

texts.en:
Sintet has been rearing and selling animals in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He is 20 years old, married and has two school-going children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD. by a friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan to buy young animals, which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

Sintet hopes to grow his business to be able to educate all his children.

loans.use: To buy young animals, which he will rear and sell later at a profit

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia T. is from the village of Siempre Viva Sur, Mallig, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Florencia is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Florencia owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Florencia has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Florencia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Florencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Florencia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Florencia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Nergui

texts.en: Nergui M. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Darhan-Uul province of central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her older daughter attends university and lives in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia while her younger daughter studies in a local secondary school. Nergui operates a used shoes retail business at an indoor stall in the Almansag market in her town. She began her business in 2000 with working capital of 1,000,000 MNT ($750). After 10 years of successful operations, she has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 2,000,000 MNT ($1,525). In the future, she plans to establish her own company and her own store. Nergui is very hard working and a diligent businesswoman. “First, I help my two daughters in their marriages to let them live separately, and then I will work very hard in order to have my own shop. I am still young and full of life energy so nothing is impossible.”she says. Nergui is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT ($1,525) loan to purchase shoes as well as to repair her husband's car.

loans.use: To purchase additionall shoes

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina B. is from the city of Macupa Tangub City. She is 54 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Josefina owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products such as soap, sardines, shampoo, cooking oil, vinegar, and more in the local community. Josefina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josefina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Margaret Sofia

texts.en:
Margaret is a tailor and has been making clothes for her clients in Naivasha town for the last two years now.  She is 45 years old and married to Samson Mokua. They have three children.

KADET has financed her growth from a small-scale tailor dealing with repairing clothes only to a big-time tailor in town. She now gets orders from organizations and individuals to make clothes for them. She is on her third loan and she plans to buy more clothing material to use in making more clothes.

She now hopes to grow the clothes business and open a boutique from where she will be selling most of her clothes. She is a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: To add more clothing fabric to her shop
